clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Accuracy of NGAL, a Renal Injury Biomarker, in Patients With Cirrhosis
clinical_study.official_title: Urinary Biomarker NGAL in Decompensated Cirrhosis: Early Prediction of AKI and of Treatment Response

collaborator.agency: Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test the accuracy of urinary neutrophil-gelatinase associated lipocalin (NGAL) and other biomarkers (plasma renin, norepinephrine) to predict acute kidney injury (AKI) development in patients with cirrhosis and bacterial infection and to predict response to AKI treatment with albumin and albumin with terlipressin in patients with suspected hepatorenal syndrome.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of NGAL to predict no response to albumin expansion
primary_outcome.description: We will build a receiver-operating curve and calculate the area under the curve to determine the accuracy of NGAL to predict no response to albumin expansion. No response will be defined as an absence of a drop of serum creatinine to a final value below 1.5mg/dL in the day after the end of albumin expansion. Albumin will be administrated as International Ascites Club recommendations, i.e. in the dose of 1g/kg/day for 2 days in patients with suspected hepatorenal syndrome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of urinary NGAL and other biomarkers to predict no response to hepatorenal syndrome treatment
secondary_outcome.description: We will test the accuracy of urinary NGAL and other biomarkers to predict no response to hepatorenal syndrome treatment. No response to treatment will be defined as a final value of serum creatinine above 1.5mg/dL after the end of treatment with terlipressin plus albumin. The treatment will be conducted according to International Ascites Club recommendations.

secondary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of urinary NGAL and other biomarkers to predict development and progression of acute kidney injury (AKI) in patients with bacterial infection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During antibiotic therapy and during hospital stay
secondary_outcome.description: We will test the accuracy of urinary NGAL and other biomarkers to predict AKI development and progression during antibiotic therapy and during hospital stay in patients with bacterial infection. AKI will be defined by ICA-AKI criteria.
We will test clinical and laboratorial data relationship with in-hospital, 30 days and 90 days mortality in a univariate analysis. Associated variables will be tested in a multivariate analysis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Urinary NGAL as a predictor of adverse events of AKI treatment in cirrhosis
secondary_outcome.description: We will build a receiver-operating curve and calculate the area under the curve to determine the accuracy of urinary NGAL to predict adverse events during AKI treatment with albumin alone or in combination with terlipressin. We will also calculate the best cut-off value based on the receiver-operating curve.

secondary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of other biomarkers to predict no response to albumin expansion
secondary_outcome.description: We will test the accuracy of other biomarkers to predict no response to albumin expansion. No response will be defined as an absence of a drop of serum creatinine to a final value below 1.5mg/dL in the day after the end of albumin expansion. Albumin will be administrated as International Ascites Club recommendations, i.e. in the dose of 1g/kg/day for 2 days in patients with suspected hepatorenal syndrome.

arm_group.description: Patients with cirrhosis admitted to hospital with bacterial infection with initial serum creatinine below 1.5mg/dL.
Patients with cirrhosis admitted to hospital with bacterial infection and initial serum creatinine above 1.5mg/dL.
Patients with cirrhosis admitted to hospital with initial serum creatinine above 1.5mg/dL without bacterial infection.

biospec_descr.textblock: We will store samples of urine and serum frozen at -80oC.

study_pop.textblock: We will include cirrhotic patients admitted to hospitals participating centers with AKI and/or bacterial infection.
